description: From Late Middle English notoryous, from Medieval Latin nōtōrius (“evident, known; famous, well-known; infamous”), from Latin nōtus (“known, recognized; familiar, widely known; famous, well-known; infamous”) + -tōrius (suffix forming adjectives). Nōtus is the perfect passive participle of nōscō (“to become acquainted with or learn about (something); (rare) to be familiar with, recognize”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *ǵneh₃- (“to know; to recognize”).

adjectives.description: notorious (comparative more notorious, superlative most notorious)

entries.meaning: Of a person or entity: generally or widely known for something negative; infamous.
Of an act, situation, etc.: blameworthy in an obvious and offensive way; blatant, flagrant.

definitionGroups.group: Senses with a favourable or neutral connotation.

entries.meaning: Generally or widely known; of common knowledge; famous or well-known.

adverbs.description: notorious (comparative more notorious, superlative most notorious)
